body: I know this is planned and somewhat unavoidable but it will have massive impact at least on applications I am overlooking.
Maybe we can keep F.Promise compatibility for for a version our two.

@richdougherty That is a good idea. We can just deprecated it for the next major version, instead of remove it.

@dotta why not a [`java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/CompletableFuture.html) instead of `java.util.concurrent.CompletionStage`?

@marcospereira `CompletableFuture` is a concrete implementation and `CompletionStage` is the interface it implements.

Maybe it'd be best to start by having `Promise` implement `CompletionStage`, which would allow it to interoperate pretty well with `CompletableFuture`.

I think making `Promise` implement `CompletionStage` is a good idea.

@marcospereira It's actually, at least in part, my fault that `CompletionStage` exists.  Though I wash my hands clean of the choice of name for it. I raised some concerns on the concurrency interest mailing list that being a concrete class, `CompletableFuture` was inappropriate for use by libraries in their APIs, since it would not interoperate well with other promise implementations.  A very late change was made to extract the `CompletionStage` interface out of it - by the time that change was made, everyone was writing blog posts on the web about `CompletableFuture`, and consequently, most people have no idea that `CompletionStage` even exists.

@jroper I knew about `CompletionStage`, but since `F.Promise` is a concrete class, it sounded reasonable to me that it should be replaced by another concrete class. But since programming to interfaces is a good practice and users will have a concrete implementation at hand (`CompletableFuture`), expose `CompletionStage` looks better.

@gmethvin very nice idea to start by having `F.Promise` implement `CompletionStage`. :+1:

I'm not against making `F.Promise` inherit from `CompletionStage`. However, if that turns out to be tricky or somewhat suboptimal, then I believe we should not be afraid of replacing `F.Promise` with `CompletionStage`.

Yes, it's a big jump, but after all Play 2.5 release is about making that jump, i.e., fully embrace java8 types and reactive streams. If we can lower the pain to upgrade, let's do it. But supporting three implementations of Futures (Java, Scala, and Play one) may be tricky and it may cost us some extra time to fully cover all use cases within Play. If this turns out to be a valid concern, then I think we should just drop `F.Promise`.

Whenever there is a serious change and lots of code needs to be changed, most people in enterprise communities will suffer. Migrations are rather painful and a lot of people want to focus on solving business problems, not technical migrations.

I think we should aim for Play 2.4 projects to compile when they're upgraded to Play 2.5. We can break compatibility in a few places if we really have to, but we should try hard to keep compatibility. We don't want it to be too much work for users to upgrade to Play 2.5, otherwise they won't upgrade.

`F.Promise` is so widely used that we should try extra hard to make sure code using `F.Promise` still works. If we can get `F.Promise` to implement `CompletionStage` then that would be great. If we can't get it to implement `CompletionStage` then we should try to find another way to make sure existing code still compiles. E.g. in Play 2.5 we could make all our APIs support both `F.Promise` and `CompletionStage`, to give people a chance to transition their code.

issue.title: Replaced `F.Function` with Java8 friends. Fix #4690

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Replaced `F.Function` with Java8 friends. Fix #4690

As explained in d24c79d85eb9f71499588d2180bfb29e6b73d55f, we are embracing Java8
functional interfaces. This commit makes the following changes:
- `F.Function0` -> `java.util.function.Supplier`
- `F.Function1` -> `java.util.function.Function`
- `F.Function2` -> `java.util.function.BiFunction`

The change is source compatible if the lambda's body passed to either of the
former `F.Function` types does not throw a checked exception. Otherwise, users
will need to update their code to catch the exception and provide the necessary
logic to deal with it.

There is however an important change affecting source compatibility, as several
of the methods in `F.Promise` used to throw (Throwable), while they don't now (
Ref #4691).

There is one additional function type that has no corresponding in the Java8
library: `F.Function3`. This type is currently only used in the `RoutingDsl`, so
I initially thought we could remove it. However, it's tricky to remove
functionality, so I decided to leave it alone for the moment, as we can always
revisit this in the future.

body:
I'm working on this at the moment.  Here's the approach I'm taking:
- `Promise` extends `CompletionStage`, and wraps a `CompletionStage`.
- All existing methods on `Promise` are deprecated, with pointers to the `CompletionStage` equivalent.  Methods that take a `Promise`, or a function that returns a `Promise`, have been modified so that they take `CompletionStage`, making all these methods compatible with any API that uses `CompletionStage`.
- All `CompletionStage` methods have been overridden to return `Promise`.  This makes for a smooth migration path, you can change a `map` to `thenApply`, but still call the result a `Promise`.
- I have not deprecated `Promise` - the reason behind this is if you deprecate a class, when someone comes to migrate, they'll see the class is deprecated, and change it `CompletionStage`, but then they'll just get compile errors on `map`/`flatMap` etc.  By not deprecating `Promise`, it encourages the smoother migration path of first changing the deprecated `map`/`flatMap` methods, which have documentation on what the `CompletionStage` alternative is, and then later you can switch from `Promise` to `CompletionStage`.
- For the rest of Play, my approach will be, any method that takes a `Promise` will be changed to take `CompletionStage`, but any method that returns a `Promise` will still return `Promise`.

Also, there are three groups of methods on `Promise` that do not have a straight forward equivalent in `CompletableFuture`, they are:
- `sequence`
- `delayed`
- `timeout`

I'm thinking of introducing a new class, `Futures`, that provides these static methods.

Hey James, I recently found out that converting a Scala Future into a Java CompletionStage is tricky. The `scala-java8-compat` library we are using does indeed allow to make the conversion with `FutureConverters.toJava(<scala-future>)`, however the returned `CompletionStage` instance cannot be converted into a `CompletableFuture` (in fact, calling `toCompletableFuture` on the returned `CompletionStage` instance will throw an exception. See the scaladoc here https://github.com/scala/scala-java8-compat/blob/master/src/main/scala/scala/compat/java8/FutureConverters.scala#L42-L55).

I'm pointing this out because we have been using the `FutureConverters` in a number of places, but we haven't really documented that the returned `CompletionStage` cannot be converted into a `CompletableFuture`.

Just wanted to put this on your radar since you are working on something somewhat related. But it may be better to open a ticket, so that we don't forget to at least update the documentation. WDYT?
